The mathematical foundations of quantum theory have been a source of controversy for over a century. The most prominent reconstruction programs have been those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. They all attempt to provide a categorical foundation for quantum theory, but none has succeeded. The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of interest to both basic and applied science. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is the result of extreme degeneration of the cnidarian body plan, including a reduction in genome size and gene content. In the case of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, the immune system is unable to eliminate the virus from the body, which is the main cause of the disease. We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this activity and that it does so by directly interacting with the Nup98-Rae1 complex, which is responsible for the nuclear import of these transcription factors. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1

The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. This increase in demand will be accompanied by a 2 °C warming of the global climate. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase to values much larger than zero. These results highlight the need for immediate investments in breeding maize for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in grasslands. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa from plant material. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, species differed in diet composition, and that dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that the diversity of large herbivores may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, and those that survive the crisis will likely face long-term challenges. We also find that many small businesses are uncertain about the length of the crisis, and some anticipate that the crisis will last for years. Finally, we find that many small businesses are planning to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic by a combination of processes, including nano-fragmentation, transference to the ocean interior, and ballasting. This study highlights the importance of size-selective sinks in the fate of floating plastic debris, and the need to better understand the processes involved in the global fate of this pollution.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important and challenging problems in astronomy and astrophysics. The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the solar system and the conditions in the early solar system. We studied the interstellar cosmic ray exposure ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are important for understanding the formation of the solar system and the conditions in the early solar system. They also provide constraints for the formation of the solar system and the conditions in the early solar system.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most fundamental traits in nature. In humans, the ability to reproduce is limited by the mother’s metabolic power. In other species, the limiting factor is the availability of resources. Here, we show that the ability to reproduce is also limited by the mother’s metabolic power in placental mammals. We show that the ability to reproduce is increased by the provision of resources to the mother, and that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. This suggests that the limiting factor in placental mammals is metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is important because it suggests that the reproductive output of placental mammals is largely determined by the mother’s physiology and behavior, rather than the availability of resources. This is a fundamental insight into the evolution of placental mammals.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to protect neurons from α-syn toxicity in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of this orphan disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, controlling blood pressure, and controlling inflammation. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of blood vessels, which is important for blood flow. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected to each other by a network of connections. The purpose of this study was to understand the structure of this network and how it controls the function of the endothelium. The results of this study will help us to understand how the endothelium controls blood pressure and inflammation, and how it can be used to treat diseases such as atherosclerosis and diabetes.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis, and the need for timely data has been clear. We have developed a data infrastructure, the COVIDcast API, that provides open access to a wide range of public health surveillance signals, including traditional signals from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, as well as many auxiliary signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This infrastructure can be used to monitor the pandemic, augment traditional public health reporting, and empower research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This finding provides a structural explanation for the physiological relevance of this phenomenon. It also provides a molecular basis for the development of new potassium channel blockers.

The gut microbiome is also dynamic, changing over time, and is influenced by the host’s diet and lifestyle. The host’s diet and lifestyle can be manipulated to influence the composition of the gut microbiome, and thus, the health of the host. The gut microbiome can also be manipulated by the use of probiotics, which can alter the composition of the gut microbiome, and thus, the health of the host. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a low probability to become dominant, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further show that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals can be reversed by nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 that enhances brain energy metabolism. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired behaviors is essential for a wide range of applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the availability of materials and the knowledge of deformation mechanisms. Here, we develop a synthesis strategy to design mechanical devices with arbitrary behaviors under large deformations, which is enabled by the use of multiple materials with distinct behaviors and their seamless collaboration. The synthesized devices are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and exhibit complex behaviors, which are physically and accurately realized. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex behaviors for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design and manufacture of mechanical devices with desired behaviors.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern is regulated by the transcription factor BCL11A. In this study, we show that the mRNA-binding protein IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of hemoglobin expression in humans. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional loss of BCL11A and the expression of fetal hemoglobin. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN), highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. Mechanistically, this resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In conclusion, hyperactive mutation of PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling protects cancer cells from oxidative stress and ferroptotic death through SREBP1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-mediated lipogenesis, and combination of PI3K-AKT-mTOR inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. (PsycINFO Database Record

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are associated with a higher risk of heart failure than other antihypertensive drugs. We show that LCCBs activate the STIM/ORAI Ca2+ sensor system, which is up-regulated in hypertension and plays a key role in vascular remodeling. Our findings suggest that LCCBs may promote vascular remodeling in patients with hypertension and may be a potential target for the development of new antihypertensive drugs. This study also provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species, which continue to decline despite the policy’s end. We also show that the policy failed to halt the decline of early-seral–associated bird species, which are now in decline on federal land. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a long and expensive process, which is why it is necessary to use computational approaches to reduce the number of compounds to be tested in vitro. In this work, we present a computational design strategy for the development of new acylide antibiotics, which is based on the prediction of their solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity to the ribosome. We tested the best candidates in vitro and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work demonstrates the potential of computational design for the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. In this work, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with a relatively small number of trainable parameters. The proposed architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with a relatively small number of trainable parameters and is easier to train and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. We also show that the proposed architecture is able to generalize to new problems, which is not always the case for existing architectures. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of adaptive radiation, where a single ancestral species radiated into a large number of species in a short period of geological time. The species flock is endemic to Lake Malawi, and the rapid diversification is thought to be a response to the dramatic changes in the lake’s hydroclimate. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of the lake’s hydroclimate, which shows that the lake underwent large-scale changes in water level, and that the evolution of the species flock coincided with periods of extreme hydroclimate variability. The results provide a unique insight into the evolution of the species flock and the role that hydroclimate variability played in the diversification of the fish. This work provides a new perspective on the role that hydroclimate variability played in the diversification of species. (Show more)

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly, but the effects of this practice on sleep are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. This study provides a unique comparison of the effects of reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device with reading a printed book, which is the most common practice. The results of this study have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is a 100-y cycle that occurred at ∼12.9 ka and is marked by a rapid global temperature drop and a change in the marine isotope stage. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio is consistent with a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Os isotopic composition of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggests mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is unknown. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, and that its expression in the thymus is essential for the development of autoreactive T cells. In contrast, CTLA-4 expression in the periphery is dispensable for the development of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of phylogenomic and genomic analyses to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding and the evolution of genes enabling lignocellulose digestion. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable lignocellulose digestion.

However, the emergence of variants with mutations that reduce or eliminate the activity of antibodies has been a major obstacle to the development of effective vaccines and therapeutics. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to optimize the structure of antibodies to neutralize variants of concern. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 variants but not the Delta variant. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of cumulative cultural evolution. This is important because it suggests that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the design of evolutionary experiments.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk. We found that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE isoform regulates the accumulation of senescent synapses in the hippocampus, which may be the result of defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a molecular mechanism for the role of APOE in AD pathogenesis. They also provide a potential therapeutic target for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. The required degree of undercooling to nucleate the stable, hexagonal, close-packed (hcp) phase of iron is too high, which is referred to as the inner core nucleation paradox. We demonstrate that the nucleation of the body-centered, cubic (bcc) phase of iron is much easier than that of the hcp phase, which can reduce the required undercooling of iron nucleation and solve the paradox. This mechanism also provides an explanation for the anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the Earth's inner core. They also have implications for the formation of other dense solids. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States, and its use is increasing among adolescents. The effects of marijuana on the brain are not well understood, and the consequences of chronic marijuana use are unknown. We show that marijuana abusers have reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the brain DA responses to methylphenidate might be a useful biomarker for the assessment of marijuana abuse and addiction. They also highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use in the human brain. (PsycINFO Database Record

Language is the defining cognitive ability of the human species. Yet, despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are only poorly understood. Here, we show that deep learning models that have been trained on unrelated tasks and datasets can be used to predict brain responses to sentences in the human brain. This suggests that predictive processing, a fundamental property of artificial intelligence, is also present in the human brain. These results provide computational and neuroscientific insights into the mechanisms of language comprehension. They also have implications for our understanding of the general principles of human cognition and for the design of artificial intelligence. (Less)

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability of DL is not a fundamental problem, but rather a consequence of the instability of the algorithms used to train DL models. We introduce a new class of algorithms, called fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which are stable and can be used to train stable DL models. We prove that FIRENETs are necessary to train stable DL models and that only a small number of layers are needed to achieve a given accuracy. We believe that this work will help to bring stability to deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the medical system to cope with the pandemic, and the failure of the public to follow the rules. One of the most frequently cited arguments is that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago, which is discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy, or Hansen's disease, is a chronic infectious disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium leprae. The disease is characterized by the loss of sensation and the formation of granulomas in the peripheral nerves and the nose, respectively. The disease is curable with multidrug therapy, but the disease is still endemic in many parts of the world. The bacterium has been the subject of intense study, and the genome sequence of the leprosy bacterium, Mycobacterium leprae, has been published. In this paper, we report the genome sequence of a second leprosy bacterium, Mycobacterium lepromatosis, and compare the two genomes. We find that the two leprosy bacilli have retained many of the same functions, despite their ancient separation, and that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved. This suggests that the leprosy bacterium has retained the same functions for a long time, and that the disease has not changed much over the course of evolution. This is an important finding, as it suggests that the leprosy bacterium is still able to cause disease in humans.

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in quantum systems is a central topic of current research. In this work, we provide a complete description of the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit for a paradigmatic model, the XX chain, in the presence of a quantum quench. We show that the entanglement dynamics is captured by a statistical ensemble with a nonzero thermodynamic entropy, which is the accumulated entanglement. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. Our result is exact in the space–time scaling limit and provides a general framework for the entanglement dynamics in quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The only available vaccine, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is expensive and requires two doses, which is a major obstacle for mass vaccination. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature. This vaccine is highly attenuated, has a short incubation period, and induces high levels of neutralizing antibodies. Importantly, the vaccine is safe and induces a strong immune response in hamsters, which were used as a relevant model for the evaluation of the vaccine. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that of rodent transmission. However, there is no consensus on the role of human ectoparasite vectors, such as fleas or lice, which are known to be able to transmit other diseases. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector and show that it fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353). This hypothesis has important implications for the understanding of the history of plague and its impact on European societies. It also has implications for the control of the disease today.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is less understood. Here, we show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also different from that of body size. We also show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also different from that of body size. We use the numbers of neurons to reconstruct the evolution of brain information-processing capacity across amniotes and show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also different from that of body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The HSP90 chaperone family is known to play a critical role in the regulation of metabolism. However, the role of TRAP1, a member of the HSP90 family, in metabolism has not been well characterized. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that are responsible for many cellular processes, including cell motility. They are also disassembled by the ADF/cofilin family of proteins, which are key regulators of the actin cytoskeleton. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin sever actin filaments remains unknown. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can induce a mechanical torque on the filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanism is critical to the ability of ADF/cofilin to sever highly connected filament networks, which are found in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for how ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in a physiological context. They also provide a general framework for understanding the role of mechanical forces in protein action. This framework can be applied to other proteins that are involved in the disassembly of filament networks.

The consumption of fructose, a common sugar found in many fruits and beverages, has been associated with weight gain. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been systematically compared with those of glucose, a common sugar found in many foods. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation of reward-processing regions and greater hunger and desire for food and a willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger appetite suppressant than glucose and may promote feeding behavior. This may help explain the increased prevalence of obesity associated with the consumption of fructose. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian language family is spoken, and it is the only island in the world where the Bantu language family is spoken. The island is also the only one in the world where the Austronesian and Bantu languages are spoken by the same population. This paper provides a detailed picture of the human history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in terms of its human population and its history. The results show that Madagascar was colonized by different groups of people from Africa and Asia, and that the colonization was not homogeneous across the island. We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. We show that people who see more positive content in their News Feed become more positive themselves, and people who see more negative content in their News Feed become more negative themselves. This work suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that the observation of others’ negative experiences can be a negative experience for people. These results have implications for the design of social networks, the spread of misinformation, and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The ribosome is the enzyme that translates messenger RNA (mRNA) into proteins. It is a complex machine that is able to read mRNA codons and translate them into amino acids. The mRNA sequence is critical for this process, and many modifications can alter the structure of the mRNA and its interaction with the ribosome. We show that the most common mRNA modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a modest effect on the translation of the mRNA. This work provides insight into how mRNA modifications can alter the interaction between the mRNA and the ribosome, and how this can impact protein synthesis. This information can be used to better understand the function of mRNA modifications and how they can be targeted to alter protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone or watching television. These associations are robust to the effects of factors such as socioeconomic status, sex, educational attainment, and age. Longitudinal analyses indicate that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with positive changes in a wide range of outcomes over a 4-y period. This feeling may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of aquatic lifestyles has been a major driver of mammalian evolution, but the extent to which aquatic lifestyles have driven the evolution of larger body sizes in mammals remains unclear. We use a quantitative model of the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment to show that aquatic lifestyles are driving the evolution of larger body sizes in mammals. This model provides a mechanistic explanation for the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals and suggests that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is likely to continue in the future.

The common cold is the most common viral infection worldwide, and the virus responsible, rhinovirus, is the most common cause of upper respiratory tract infections. The temperature at which rhinovirus replicates most efficiently in the nasal cavity (33–35 °C) is cooler than the core body temperature (37 °C). We show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a more robust antiviral defense response at 37 °C than at 33 °C, and that this correlates with higher levels of type I and type III IFNs and ISGs at 37 °C. These findings suggest that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is, at least in part, due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. This may be important for understanding the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus in the nasal cavity, and may also have implications for the development of antiviral therapies. Bacteria use a variety of sensory systems to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanochemical system is used to regulate the activity of the Chp chemosensory system, which in turn regulates the expression of virulence factors and biofilm formation. This system is important for the pathogenicity of P. aeruginosa, as it allows the bacterium to sense surfaces and respond accordingly.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and the use of insecticides in particular has been associated with a decline in aquatic biodiversity. However, the extent of the problem is not well understood because of a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global metaanalysis of the occurrence of pesticides in surface water and the risk they pose to aquatic biodiversity. We show that the use of insecticides in agriculture is a major threat to the quality of global surface water resources. Our results suggest that the use of pesticides in agriculture should be reduced worldwide, and that the use of newer-generation insecticides should be phased out. This is a necessary step to protect the quality of global surface water resources.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the emergence of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes it, has been a major public health concern. The virus has been shown to be transmitted between humans, but the extent to which it is transmitted between animals is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a common North American cervid. We also show that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter, when human transmission is at its lowest. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology and evolution of SARS-CoV-2. This will require a One Health approach to study the virus in both humans and animals. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the impacts of these dams, and the solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices. We find that the proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a result of the lack of a global framework for hydropower, the lack of a global framework for climate change, and the lack of a global framework for sustainable development. We also find that the impacts of large dams are overestimated and the costs are underestimated. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins in the brain. The exact cause of AD is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we show that soluble Aβ is toxic to neurons, and that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain is not necessary for the production of inflammatory factors. We also show that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons is a significant factor in the development of inflammation in the brain. This study provides a better understanding of the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is known from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the majority of the chicken bones belong to adult individuals, which is a rare observation in the archaeological record. We argue that the observed pattern is a result of the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and their gradual integration into the local economy, which was fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period. This process was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biochemistry. The folding of a single protein is a complex process that involves a large number of steps and is influenced by many factors. The study of the folding of individual proteins is therefore a powerful tool for understanding the general principles of protein folding. Here we report the results of a detailed study of the folding of the maltose binding protein, a large protein that is known to fold in two distinct steps. The results show that the folding of the protein involves a fast collapse into a polyglobular state, followed by a slower formation of a distinct intermediate, and finally to the native state. The results also show that the intermediate is an obligatory step on the folding pathway. This is a major step forward in our understanding of protein folding. (Show more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular mechanisms that control the levels of these molecules and the extent to which they are involved in the regulation of gene expression remain largely unknown. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme RppH, which is known to remove the cap of the viral RNA virus 5′ terminal, also removes the cap of Np4-capped RNAs. This enzyme, which is inactivated by stress, is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress, and it preferentially removes Np4-capped RNAs over their triphosphorylated counterparts. This unique mechanism of decapping, which is distinct from the one used to remove other 5′ termini, could have major consequences for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality rates. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanisms involved in the dysfunction of the immune system are still unknown. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore immune function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. We found that arginine supplementation was more efficient than citrulline supplementation in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This work also provides a new therapeutic strategy for sepsis patients. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is the total amount of carbon and other elements that living organisms contain. It is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the global marine biomass for the functioning of the biosphere. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. This work is expected to be a reference for many years to come.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts and the relation of our model to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena.

However, diamond is brittle and can break under mechanical stress. This work shows that diamond can be made to behave like a metal, with a vanishing bandgap, under mechanical strain. This is a new property of diamond, which can be used to control its properties for applications. The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the development of the nodule, and the mechanisms of antifungal activity of nodule-specific peptides are poorly understood. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a unique NCR peptide, which is highly expressed in the nodule, and its structural architecture. We also report the mode of action of this peptide against plant fungal pathogens, and its potential as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sexual selection and the evolution of sex differences. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a common human bleeding disorder. The mechanism also explains the effects of mutations in VWF, which are often used to classify the disease. The mechanism is also relevant to other proteins that bind to receptors on the cell surface. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that is intimately linked to our health. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in and on us, is poorly understood. Here, we present a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which we use to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. We find that the human virome is far more complex than the bacteriome, and that it is linked to a wide range of diseases. This database will be a valuable resource for the scientific community, and will help us to understand the human microbiome and its impact on health.

The temperature history of Earth’s surface is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present a method for reconstructing ancient surface temperatures based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are important for the normal function of the cell and the body. The two types of ion-conducting pore gates, one for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other for slow inactivation/recovery, are commonly present in ion channels. The K+ channel BK lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. (Show more)

The malaria parasite is able to invade the human red blood cell (RBC) and establish a blood stage infection. The invasion process is a complex event involving a number of parasite proteins, but the identity of the host cell receptors and the mechanisms by which they are recognized by the parasite are not fully understood. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This is an important finding, as it suggests that the invasion process is not a simple one-way process, but rather a dynamic interaction between the parasite and host cell. This is likely to have important implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and it is difficult to control its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be completely metallized. This opens up opportunities to control the properties of diamond via strain engineering. This work can help to develop diamond-based technologies for applications in the future.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome, and suggest that dry air may be a potential environmental risk factor for seasonal influenza. Our study also provides a rationale for the development of humidity-based influenza vaccine adjuvants. (PsycINFO Database Record

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is based on a model of language that is too simple to capture the complexity of the brain’s activity. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of a sentence is not sequential, but rather involves a merge operation that applies equally to words and phrases. This merge operation is consistent with a bottom-up parser that first identifies phrases and then merges them into larger phrases. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language may help to explain the brain’s efficient processing of language. (PsycINFO Database Record

We show that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms of the Wnt pathway and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for diseases that are regulated by this pathway. Nitrogen is the most limiting macronutrient for global crop production, and the ability to engineer nitrogen fixation in plants would be a major advance in agriculture. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacterium from the plant side, rather than the other way around, is a key step toward this goal. Here, we demonstrate the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacterium from the plant side, using a synthetic signaling system that allows the plant to control the expression of genes in the nitrogen-fixing bacterium. This work represents a major step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. This system could be used to deliver nitrogen in agriculture, and could also be used to engineer nitrogen-fixing symbioses in other plants, such as legumes, which are important for the nitrogen cycle in nature. The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a major cause of climate change. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, the Amazon is losing forest at an accelerating rate. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to reduce deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in the program, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. This is particularly important given the increasing use of remote-sensed deforestation alerts in the Amazon.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. We show that the orb-spinning spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body, because its web acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider’s web is made of protein and is self-manufactured, so it is not constrained by the body size of the spider. The spider can therefore increase its acoustic sensitivity enormously by outsourcing its ears to its web. This provides a unique model for studying how to design acoustic sensors and for developing new acoustic devices. It also provides a new perspective on the evolution of hearing in animals.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and aerosols are difficult to disentangle, and both are important for the global climate. We show that removing fossil-fuel-related emissions and aerosols can save millions of lives and restore rainfall patterns, and reduce global warming by 0.51(±0.03) °C. However, the climate benefits are offset by the warming from aerosols, and the temperature increase from removing fossil-fuel-related emissions and aerosols is 0.73(±0.03) °C. Therefore, the climate benefits are limited to 0.22(±0.03) °C, and the temperature increase from removing fossil-fuel-related emissions and aerosols is 0.28(±0.03) °C. This is still a substantial reduction in global warming, and the climate benefits are likely to increase with the removal of other anthropogenic sources. Our results show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The availability of vaccines is critical to ending the pandemic. We report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing. This protein is highly immunogenic, and presentation of the protein on a virus-like particle (VLP) can further enhance the immune response. This engineered protein can be produced in large quantities by a well-established technology, and we anticipate that it will be a useful tool for vaccine development.

The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are expressed in the developing nervous system. They are implicated in the development of the nervous system in humans and in the regulation of the neuroblastoma ALK/Ltk receptor in mice. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKALs activate the zebrafish Ltk receptor in vivo, and that zebrafish Ltk is sufficient to activate human ALK/Ltk in vitro. We also show that zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, a type of neural crest-derived cells. Finally, we show that zebrafish ALKALs are required for zebrafish and human ALK/Ltk receptor signaling. Taken together, our results provide in vivo evidence for the involvement of ALKALs in neural crest development and in the activation of ALK/Ltk receptors. This is important for understanding the role of ALK/Ltk in neuroblastoma and for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The emergence of Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, is one of the most dramatic events in human history, with devastating consequences for both humans and animals. The pathogen has been documented in the archaeological record as early as the Neolithic, but the number of genomes available to date is too small to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia, which provide a more complete picture of the pathogen’s evolution and ecology during this period. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not only able to adapt to the new host, but also to rapidly spread across continents. This study provides a more complete picture of the formative years of plague, which is crucial for understanding its evolution and spread throughout history. (Less)

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, hegemonic masculinity predicted less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors associated with spillover and used this to rank the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery and surveillance efforts, and used this to identify the top 12 ranked viruses. We created a publicly available web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the risk factors associated with spillover and to prioritize the investigation of viruses of greatest concern. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying the production of nectar pigments are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a second alkaloid in the red nectar of Jaltomata herrerae, a hummingbird-visited species, suggesting that this type of adaptation is convergent. Our findings provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of a red nectar trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species. This work also identifies a limited number of compounds that are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work contributes to our understanding of the evolution of nectar chemistry and its role in plant–pollinator interactions. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood, and the impact of this period on the genetic structure of Europe is still debated. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a large sample of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly during the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestry of women is highly heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that the impact of the Migration Period on the genetic structure of Europe was more complex than previously thought. Our results also indicate that the genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period is more complex than previously thought.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. The ability to rapidly identify pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating epidemics. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic sequencing of RNA from febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya, dengue, and malaria. We also identified HIV, which is endemic in Cambodia, in a patient with undifferentiated fever. The lagging strand of the DNA double helix is synthesized by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical for the synthesis of the lagging strand, but the mechanism by which it is maintained is unknown. We developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the holoenzyme is not very processive and is very unstable. These results have profound implications for the synthesis of the lagging strand in humans as they limit the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promote the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results also suggest that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more similar to the S. cerevisiae holoenzyme than previously thought. This is important because the S. cerevisiae pol δ holoenzyme is a model for the human pol δ holoenzyme.

The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in science. The hypothesis that life began with the synthesis of RNA molecules is based on the observation that the building blocks of life, nucleotides, can associate to form RNA molecules. However, the details of how this process occurred in the past are unknown. In this paper, we describe an approach that can be used to test the hypothesis that life began with the synthesis of RNA molecules.

We use computer vision to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We then use this measure to study the factors that predict neighborhood improvement. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the initial appearance of the neighborhood, the density of college-educated adults, and the proximity of the neighborhood to the central business district. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change: the “invasion” theory, the “tipping” theory, and the “accumulation” theory. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods is a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the people who live there. This is an important contribution to the literature on urban change because it provides a new way to study the physical dynamics of cities. It also has important implications for urban planning because it suggests that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the people who live there. Finally, our results suggest that computer vision methods and time-series street-level imagery may be useful tools for studying the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear, and the treatment is still in the stage of trial and error. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can significantly improve the clinical outcomes of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic to cells. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is well established, but the existence of copper-binding metabolites in fungi has not been demonstrated. We report the identification of a copper-binding isocyanide biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus, and demonstrate that this cluster is expressed in vitro and in vivo, and is induced by copper. The copper-binding properties of xan BGC-derived isocyanides are demonstrated in vitro and in vivo, and the ability of xan BGC metabolites to mediate interactions with pathogenic microbes is described. These results suggest that fungal natural products may play a role in the regulation of copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. This is an important discovery, as it suggests that fungal natural products may be involved in the regulation of metal homeostasis in other organisms. This is the first report of a fungal natural product that binds and impacts cellular copper content. This is a significant discovery, as it suggests that fungal natural products may be involved in the regulation of metal homeostasis in other organisms.

Frost damage is a major threat to the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to the ongoing climate change, and that the resistance strategies of trees are also changing accordingly. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk and to minimize the economic and ecological impact of late-spring frosts. They can also help to develop frost-resistant cultivars and to improve the resilience of forests to climate change. Our results are expected to be of interest to a broad audience, including scientists, policy makers, and the general public.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of Th17 cells are unknown. We found that Th17 cells could provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells, but that the development of Th1-like cells required the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the cells responsible for generating movement. The disease is caused by mutations in genes that encode proteins, and the most common cause is a superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) mutation. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients, which can be used to study the disease and develop therapeutics. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate motor neuron toxicity. This will help us to understand the disease and develop new treatments. This will be particularly important for ALS patients with SOD1 mutations, who are the most common cause of the disease. This method will also be applicable to other diseases that cause motor neuron degeneration.

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the insect microbiota is a key factor in the transmission of infectious diseases. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of Anaplasma to colonize the vector. We demonstrate that the protein binds to the bacterial cell wall, perturbing the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and the ability of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the insect microbiota and suggest that targeting the gut microbiota may be a potential strategy for controlling vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of vertebrates. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary event in the origin of the modern avian bauplan. However, the currently known diversity of early branching members of this group obscures our understanding of the origin of the modern avian tail. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the origin of the avian tail and the mosaic evolution of the avian tail.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system by studying the system in its entirety. Instead, we study the system in pieces, and then we try to put the pieces together to understand the system as a whole. In this paper, we study the role of stratospheric water vapor in the climate system. We show that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, and we estimate the strength of the resulting feedback to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which is a significant contribution to the overall climate sensitivity.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This phenomenon is called color polymorphism. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green color in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. We describe these proteins, hereafter named biliverdin-binding serpins (BBSs), and show that they are most similar to human alpha-1-antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. We believe that our findings will help to understand the evolution of color polymorphism in vertebrates. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are thought to be responsible for the initiation and maintenance of metastasis. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn regulates the expression of NANOG, a key factor in the maintenance of BCSC phenotype. This study provides a mechanism for the role of hypoxia in the maintenance of BCSCs, and suggests that targeting ALKBH5 may be a potential therapeutic strategy for breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first pocket Bible was produced in the 13th century. The source of the parchment used to make these Bibles has been a long-standing controversy. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used, but others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many Bibles were made from fetal skins. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. This suggests that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.
