The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing, magnitude, and rate of change in the carbon cycle suggest that it was a global environmental perturbation. This study provides a precise age model for the extinction and its aftermath, allowing a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. The results also provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The results will also be important for understanding the timing of ecosystem recovery. This is the first time that a precise age model has been established for the Permian-Triassic boundary.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the gut lumen, and its dysfunction is associated with the development of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The nuclear retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays a crucial role in maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. However, the role of RORα in the intestinal inflammation remains unclear. Here, we report that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including IBD. Our study provides insights into the role of RORα in intestinal inflammation and suggests a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in circulating variants, and it is thought to increase infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike in the D614G and G614 variants and show that the G614 spike is more open and may facilitate receptor binding. This may explain the increased infectivity of G614 variants. Our results provide insights into the mechanism of action of the D614G mutation and may inform the design of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003, and that the Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Our findings underscore the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected, and to close the racial health disparities that have persisted for generations.

The chemical properties of atoms are fundamental to chemistry, and they are the basis for the classification of elements and compounds. The chemical properties of atoms are also the basis for the classification of chemical reactions, which is the basis for the classification of chemical processes. Thus, the chemical properties of atoms are the basis for chemistry. We show that the chemical properties of atoms change with pressure, and that these changes are consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. We also show that the changes in chemical properties are consistent with the changes in chemical reactivity.

Fire is a key natural process in terrestrial ecosystems, but its role in the climate system is complex, with feedbacks that can amplify or attenuate warming. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been the dominant drivers of fire activity in the 20th century, but that recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may reverse this, enhancing land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. We show that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks, as caused by changing fire regimes, are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights that ignitions and fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our results have implications for the management of fire in the context of climate change. (Show more)

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. We also show that the timing of glycan provision is critical for the maintenance of the symbiosis, and that the glycan must be catabolized by the symbiont in order to maintain the luminescence of the organ. These results suggest that the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery may be a general strategy used by animals to regulate the health of their symbionts. This strategy may be particularly important in the context of the immune system, where the delivery of nutrients to microbes may be critical for the maturation of the immune response. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a sparse representation of an embedding space to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent discourse atoms. We then use a generative model to infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We believe that this approach will be useful in many domains.

The Black Death, the deadliest epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that the Black Death was the consequence of repeated introductions of Y. pestis into European harbors, which were caused by climate-driven changes in the distribution of Asian reservoirs of the bacterium. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of a series of introductions, rather than a single introduction, and that the disease was not established in Europe until the end of the 1340s. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the Black Death and the second plague pandemic. It also has implications for our understanding of the spread of plague in the modern era, where the introduction of the bacterium into Europe is also understood as a single event.

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is a disease outbreak affecting a large number of asteroid species on the Pacific Coast of North America. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the animal. We show that the disease is caused by a virus, and that the virus is transmitted by the sea stars themselves. The virus is also present in the plankton, sediments, and in nonasteroid echinoderms, suggesting that it can spread through the marine ecosystem. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality in sea stars.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common type of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML is poor, with a high mortality rate. The IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody targeting IL1RAP can be used to treat AML in mice, and that this antibody can block IL-1 signaling. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach could be used to treat other types of cancer as well. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history and a unique genetic structure. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, with a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it has implications for the settlement of the Indian Ocean islands. (Show more)

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with a membrane-bound enzyme and increases the activity of that enzyme. The protein also interferes with the ability of a second RNA to repress the expression of two other genes. The protein interferes with the ability of the second RNA to repress the expression of the two other genes, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate multiple biological processes.

The ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize viruses is a key component of the immune system. However, antibodies can mutate and lose their ability to neutralize viruses, which is a major obstacle to the development of antiviral and vaccine therapies. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize antibodies to neutralize variants of concern. We demonstrate the utility of our approach by optimizing an antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 variants but not the Delta variant. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s neutralizing activity against the Delta variant. Our optimized antibody can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-SeekBar the virus variants. This work highlights the power of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential application to the development of antiviral and vaccine therapies. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to convert the original crop expert assessments into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used in quantitative analyses. We show that the resulting crop condition index is robust to the subjective nature of the original crop expert assessments, and can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Our results show the potential of using crop expert assessments to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. This could have important implications for food security, agricultural production, and the management of agricultural risks.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative view that relies on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability to store information. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear, with some studies showing an increase in soil respiration with warming and others showing no change. We provide a synthesis of the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis provides limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our results add a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. (PsycINFO Database Record

The plastid genome is the most reduced organelle genome, and its molecular evolution is shaped by the host plant’s genome and the environment. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life, and it is accompanied by a stepwise relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is timely, given the upcoming United Nations Climate Change Conference in Madrid. (more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the field of materials science. However, the conditions under which they are formed are not fully understood. We report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this anthropogenic quasicrystal provides a unique link between the discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the development of nuclear weapons.

The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key reaction in photosynthesis. The first step of this reaction, catalyzed by a single enzyme in plants and cyanobacteria, is a key step in photosynthesis. The second step, catalyzed by a second enzyme in plants and cyanobacteria, is a key step in oxygenic photosynthesis. The evolution of the two enzymes is discussed herein.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS), and is associated with the development of disability. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in the regulation of cell survival. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes may be potential therapeutic targets for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for MS. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest period on record and led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in recent decades, and that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased substantially. We attribute this increase to anthropogenic warming, which has increased the probability of dry precipitation years being also warm. This finding has important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and climate adaptation planning in California and elsewhere. It also has implications for the interpretation of climate model results, which have been used to argue that anthropogenic warming has not increased the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions. Our results suggest that the probability of such conditions has increased substantially in recent decades, and that this probability will continue to increase in the future.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a broad phenotypic spectrum. The etiology of ASD is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. Here, we show that the reversal-learning task, which is a behavioral measure of behavioral flexibility, is a converging target of the autism-risk genes. These autism-risk genes all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. The reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for ASD-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for the convergence of autism-risk genes and may facilitate the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that, on average, people react more strongly to negative news content than positive news content, and that this negativity bias is present in a wide variety of countries and cultures. This work thus helps to account for the prevalence of negative news content around the world, and it also highlights the potential for more positive news content to be more widely consumed.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in the channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 are associated with immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which result in a Stormorken-like syndrome of bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, and tubular myopathy. We also identify a Stormorken-like syndrome in ORAI1, which is associated with hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process, but the mechanisms underlying this propagation are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on endocytic trafficking and that the release of aggregates from the cell is important for disease progression. These findings provide a platform for studying the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases and for developing therapeutic strategies to prevent or reverse the spread of aggregates. (Show more)

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immunologically privileged, which is thought to be important for the maintenance of a healthy microbial community in the bat gut. However, the mechanisms underlying the immunologically privileged status of bats remain unclear. Here, we identified a protein, MTX, which is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX is a potent inhibitor of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H), which is a key enzyme in the biosynthesis of the lipid mediator leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent chemoattractant for host defense against infection. We found that MTX facilitated viral infection by inhibiting the antiviral immune response of the host and by inducing immune tolerance. This study provides deeper insight into the immunologically privileged status of bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human cytosolic and mitochondrial serine hydroxymethyltransferse (SHMT1/2), which blocks tumor growth in a mouse model. We have also identified a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically. This work provides a rationale for the development of small-molecule dual SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapy. It also provides a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state is likely the result of a combination of factors, including the presence of a variety of toxic species, such as metal ions, and the presence of a variety of cellular stressors, such as oxidative stress. This study provides a new perspective on the neuropathology of ALS, which may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that this work will inspire future research on the physics and applications of 2D photonic crystals.

The origin of the Ceratophyllum clade is poorly understood, and the age of the earliest aquatic angiosperms is also unknown. Montsechia, a plant from the early Cretaceous, is the first aquatic angiosperm to be described in 100 y. Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, and the two are aquatic plants that reproduce below the surface of the water. This opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, and it is important to understand the evolutionary history of the viruses that infect humans. Here we present the first ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) sequences, which show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred at a time when humans were expanding out of Africa. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and the rate of sea level rise is accelerating. These observations are consistent with the hypothesis that the climate is warming, and the rate of sea level rise is increasing because the climate is warming. The rate of sea level rise is a key indicator of the effectiveness of climate policy, and the acceleration of sea level rise is a key indicator of the effectiveness of climate policy in reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that pain has increased more rapidly with age for those born after 1950, the so-called “baby boomers.” This increase is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates is a key goal of structural biology. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of an enzyme intermediate. This approach provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the reaction pathway, including the location of the leaving group, the hydrogen bond donor, and the nucleophile. This detailed picture of the reaction pathway is key to understanding the mechanism of the enzyme. This work highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by the MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV). There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS-CoV infection, and the available options are limited to supportive care. We show that prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment can prevent and treat MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model, and that remdesivir treatment can be given orally. These data support the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir has also been shown to be effective against SARS-CoV, and may therefore be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This is an important step forward in the development of antiviral treatments for coronavirus infections. This study was funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (OPP1174228). The funders had no role in study design, data collection and interpretation, or the decision to submit the work for publication. The authors declare no conflicts of interest. The funders had no role in study design, data collection and interpretation, or the decision to submit the work for publication.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. We also show that the timing of glycan provision is critical for the maintenance of the symbiosis, and that the glycan must be catabolized by the symbiont in order to maintain the luminescence of the organ. These results suggest that the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery may be a general strategy used by animals to regulate the health of their symbionts. This strategy may be particularly important in the context of the immune system, where the delivery of nutrients to microbes may be critical for the maturation of the immune response. (Show more)

The suspension rate in US schools is 10 times higher than it was in 1992. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline, and that this can reduce suspension rates. It also shows that students’ respect for teachers and motivation to behave well in class can be sustained by this approach. This has important implications for the future of US schools.

DNA alkylation is one of the major sources of DNA damage, which can lead to transcriptional mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional mutagenesis induced by alkylation remain unknown. Here, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis. We found that the transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. To infect cells, MERS-CoV must first bind to cell receptors, and then fuse with the cell membrane. We found that the spike (S) glycoproteins, which mediate these events, are cleaved sequentially during cell entry. We also found that the first cleavages, which are required for the second, fusion-activating cleavage, are cell type specific. These findings suggest that the sequential cleavage of MERS-CoV S proteins is a determinant of the virus’s tropism for human lung-derived cells, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and is a major contributor to the global obesity epidemic. The food choices of the population as a whole have a large influence on these outcomes, and it is therefore important to understand how to encourage people to make healthier choices. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of people choosing vegetarian meals by 40%. This is equivalent to the effect of a large-scale government policy, and is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in many settings. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings could have a large impact on the environment and population health. This is an important step toward achieving more sustainable diets. (Less)

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its extracellular environment. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the surfaceome is the collection of all the proteins that are exposed to the extracellular space. We have developed a method to measure the surfaceome of a cell line stably expressing a specific oncogene, and we have applied this to six of the most prominent oncogenes in breast cancer. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with a method to measure the glycoproteome, and we find that each oncogene has a different glycoproteome, but that the glycoproteome is also harmonized by common biological themes. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Less)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. They also suggest that vote-by-mail programs are unlikely to have a significant impact on the 2020 presidential election.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has been shown to spread rapidly through the population, and the molecular basis for this is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. We show that the structure of ORF8 is similar to SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a, but with the addition of two unique interfaces. These interfaces may be used to mediate immune suppression and evasion, and may also be used to form unique large-scale assemblies. These results provide insight into the molecular basis for the rapid spread of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, which is a life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying this condition are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic induction of the corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF)/CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) axis. We also show that CRFR1 signaling in astrocytes contributes to the up-regulation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1), which are both involved in the pathogenesis of edema. These findings provide a molecular understanding of the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema induced by hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for this condition. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It arises in many areas of research, including genomics, finance, and climate science. It is a problem of great practical importance, because it addresses the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in the face of the fact that we have “cherry picked” the data. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this article will help to make the problem and its solutions more accessible to a broad audience.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the conversion of human fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. Furthermore, the use of ETV2-transduced human fibroblasts can be applied to the generation of ECs for clinical applications, such as the treatment of ischemic disorders and the development of vascular networks for the regeneration of damaged organs. These findings may also provide a new strategy for the generation of ECs for the treatment of ischemic disorders and the development of vascular networks. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) were identified as oncogenes. Recently, two ligands, ALKAL1 (also named “augmentor-β” or “FAM150A”) and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-α” or “FAM150B”), were discovered. Here, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also show that these ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation in the eye and in the body. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a better understanding of the function of Alk and Ltk and their ligands in vivo. It also provides a model for the study of the function of other orphan RTKs. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder characterized by insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of STING in peripheral tissues has been well characterized, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired insulin secretion. Mechanistically, STING deficiency down-regulated Pax6 expression, which is required for normal insulin secretion. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide insights into the development of therapeutic strategies for T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are composed of eight genomic RNA segments, which are packaged into virions. The packaging of the viral genome is a highly conserved process, but the molecular details of the packaging mechanism are unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. We show that this interaction is required for optimal viral replication and that it favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results provide insights into the packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses and suggest that the interaction we identified is a key step in the packaging process. This interaction might be important for the genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our findings also suggest that the packaging of the influenza A virus genome is sequence dependent. This is the first time that a sequence-dependent packaging mechanism has been identified in any virus. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in the arterial wall. The atheroprone hemodynamic environment is a key factor in the development of atherosclerosis. However, the mechanisms underlying the atheroprone hemodynamic environment-induced vascular phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions are not fully understood. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the atheroprone hemodynamic environment is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a molecular mechanism for the atheroprone hemodynamic environment-induced vascular phenotypes and atherogenesis and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study also provides a rationale for the development of athero-protective drugs targeting YAP/TAZ. (PsycINFO Database Record

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have altered the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. This is largely due to the expansion of the “fire niche” in the United States, which is largely due to human activities. We show that human-caused wildfires have increased in both extent and frequency, and that the human-caused fire season is up to three times longer than the lightning-caused fire season. We recommend that actions to reduce fire risk and associated hazards should focus on reducing the risk of human-caused wildfires.

We use computer vision to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. Specifically, we find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements, and neighborhoods that are physically proximate to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience physical improvements. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. (Less)

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly pest control method, which is widely used in agriculture and public health. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods are still unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated dTRPγ ion channel as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents in Drosophila melanogaster. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is long, suggesting that the eclipse phase for ZIKV is short. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load, whereas the antiviral treatment favipiravir given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results can help guide the development of antiviral therapies for ZIKV. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, a response to environmental stress. The loss of the symbiosis is often followed by the death of the coral host. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. We demonstrate that the metabolic energy demand of the coral host increases during heat stress, which is compensated by the degradation of amino acids. This shift from uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients. It also mounts immune responses and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and stimulate tumor growth. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome and highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides insights into the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This study also provides a model system to study the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work also provides insights into the role of the microbiome in tumor

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, and the response to chemotherapy is often poor. We found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize or reengraft mice. We also found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with a humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The timing of the last deglaciation is one of the most important questions in Quaternary science. The onset of deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, which would have led to a reduction in Southern Ocean sea-level rise and a reduction in the rate of Antarctic ice-sheet retreat. However, this explanation is challenged by the fact that deglaciation started only after a volcanic eruption series, which is known to have led to stratospheric ozone depletion, and that this series is not associated with a change in Southern Hemisphere climate. Here, we show that the volcanic eruptions led to a reduction in stratospheric ozone, which is consistent with the observed changes in climate and ice-sheet dynamics. This finding provides a unique link between the chemistry of the atmosphere and the timing of the last deglaciation. It also has implications for the timing of deglaciation on other planets. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but are often overlooked in conservation and policy discussions. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and fishery sustainability. We find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis also reveals that fishing pressure is most intense in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors, highlighting the need to protect biodiversity in freshwater ecosystems. Our data can be used to inform the design of policies to protect and restore riverine ecosystems and improve the sustainability of inland fisheries. This is particularly important in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors, such as in many developing countries.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the proposed material are responsible for the high capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating, and the few regenerating neurons are limited to a small number of cell types. In C. elegans, a well-characterized form of ectopic axon outgrowth is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite and is dependent on DLK-1/DLK signaling. Here, we show that this DLK-dependent form of axon outgrowth is also triggered by sensory activity, and we identify a second form of ectopic axon outgrowth that is DLK-independent and is triggered by sensory activity in the absence of DLK signaling. These findings suggest that the molecular mechanisms controlling the onset of axon outgrowth are conserved in the adult mammalian CNS. Moreover, the DLK-independent form of axon outgrowth is a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired to create genetic diversity. It is a key step in the evolution of new traits, and it is also important for the maintenance of genome integrity. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no evidence of recombination, and others showing intense recombination. These results provide a detailed view of recombination in a flowering plant, and they provide a foundation for future studies of recombination in other plants and in animals.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, which are dynamically active in a context-dependent manner. This hypothesis has been tested using functional MRI, which measures the dynamic fluctuations of neuronal activity. However, the results are highly variable across subjects, and the number of networks is still debated. We used a different imaging technique, positron emission tomography, to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network, whereas in Parkinson’s disease this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. The dominant RSN was also deactivations during task performance, which was reduced in early Parkinson’s disease and partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This study illustrates the potential of metabolic imaging to provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for translation. We show that a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group, is also found on the 5′ ends of some nuclear and mitochondrial mRNAs. This 5′ NAD+ cap is found on subsets of transcripts that are not 5′ end processed, suggesting that it may have a role in regulating mRNA stability and translation.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control during the trial was associated with a reduction in the incidence of microvascular complications in people with type 1 and type 2 diabetes. However, the long-term effects of intensive glucose control on the progression of complications are unknown. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells from people with diabetes persist for several years after the end of the DCCT and may contribute to the metabolic memory of intensive glucose control. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory and may provide a target for the development of new therapies to prevent complications in people with diabetes. (PsycINFO Database Record

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and lacks effective targeted therapies. We show that the tumor suppressor protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. We also show that FSIP1 is required for the growth of TNBC cells in vitro and in vivo and that it promotes autophagy, inhibits mTOR and Wnt/β-catenin signaling, and enhances AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) activity. These findings suggest that FSIP1 may be a potential therapeutic target for TNBC. This study may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic relapsing disorder with high mortality and morbidity rates. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier dysfunction and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. (PsycINFO Database Record

The tomato is a model system for the study of plant–environment interactions, and the fruit is a model system for the study of plant–animal interactions. The fruit is also a model system for the study of the biosynthesis of volatile organic compounds, which are emitted by plants and animals and play a key role in the interactions between them. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the identification of the genes involved is a major step forward in understanding the interactions between plants and animals.

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, the impacts of these two factors on ecosystem functioning are frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that the impacts of global warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are dependent on the thermal tolerance of species. We found that as temperatures shifted from ambient conditions, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning became steeper, meaning that more species were required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for our understanding of the impacts of climate change on ecosystems and the design of effective conservation strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to represent different aspects of the environment. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice, and we found that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for navigation, are organized anatomically, while border, head-direction, and object-vector cells tend to intermingle. These data suggest that grid cells might be largely distinct from those of other cell types. Our results also suggest that grid cells might be more strongly coupled to each other than to other cell types. This study provides a detailed view of the organization of MEC neurons in freely behaving mice. It will be useful for understanding the function of MEC in navigation. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes and environmental cues. In many plants, flowering is regulated by a mobile signal, which is able to travel from the leaves to the shoot apex to induce flowering. In this study, we show that the flowering signal, FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT), is able to induce flowering of the parasitic plant Cuscuta australis, even though the FT gene in dodder does not function in flowering. We further show that host-synthesized FT signals are able to move into dodder stems, where they physically interact with a dodder transcription factor to activate dodder flowering. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. (Show more)

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The dopamine-containing nigral system also includes the striosome–dendron bouquet, a specialized integrative subsystem that is not well understood. We used a variety of techniques to characterize the morphology of the bouquet, which is composed of striosomes, dopamine-containing dendrites, and afferents. We found that the bouquet is composed of many tightly intertwined striosomal fibers and dopamine-containing dendrites, and that the striosomal fibers and dendrites are also connected to a variety of other neurons and glia. We suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquet is a specialized integrative subsystem within the dopamine-containing nigral system that is critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we’re feeling connected to someone? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed at which we respond to others is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. We found that people felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them, and that listeners perceived conversations with faster response times as more connected. This finding suggests that we can use the speed at which we respond to others to assess whether we are feeling connected to them. This may be a useful heuristic for social interaction, and may even be used by others to assess our connection to them.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells (SANCs) are the only cells in the heart that are able to autonomously generate action potentials, and thus are responsible for the heart rate. SAN automaticity is regulated by a complex network of channels and stores that are activated in a coordinated fashion to maintain SAN automaticity. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN automaticity, and that it is expressed in a subpopulation of SANCs. We show that STIM1 regulates SAN automaticity by modulating the activity of channels on the plasma membrane and the size of the SR stores. These studies reveal a previously unknown mechanism by which STIM1 regulates SAN automaticity. This mechanism may be important for the maintenance of SAN automaticity in health and disease. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore resistance has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is dependent on jasmonate (JA), a key signaling molecule involved in insect herbivore resistance. Our results suggest that Si priming of JA-mediated defense responses may be a key mechanism underlying the insect-resistant effect of Si. These findings provide insights into the potential of Si as a sustainable pest-management tool. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We further show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative view where memory is supported by a mechanism that reduces firing rates. This mechanism is adaptive, and information is read back into the system to be processed. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds, and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall in plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures determine their ability to internalize into plant cells and deliver biomolecules. We also show that the internalization efficiency of DNA nanostructures correlates with their respective gene silencing efficiencies but that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the siRNA attachment locus. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the context of plant biology, synthetic biology, and agriculture. (Show more)

Nutrient loading from small tributaries is a major concern for the health of large lakes, but it has been largely overlooked in regulatory efforts and monitoring programs. We show that the majority of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the world’s fifth largest lake by volume, Lake Michigan, come from a small fraction of its tributaries. These small tributaries are also more biologically available to fuel algal blooms, which can have severe impacts on the ecosystem and the economy of the Great Lakes region. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication and suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to these areas. This could help protect the valuable nearshore ecosystems of large lakes and the economic benefits they provide to the region. Our findings also demonstrate the need to consider the spatial heterogeneity of nutrient sources in large water bodies, which can be driven by a variety of factors, including land cover, topography, and the presence of dams.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network that is coupled to an environment that provides work to the system only in rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the system exhibits a strong tendency to concentrate in states that extremize the environmental work. This behavior is reminiscent of the “optimal fluctuation” phenomenon in physics, which has been observed in a variety of systems. We argue that the observed behavior is a consequence of the interplay between the intrinsic dynamics of the system and the environmental forcing.

The mechanisms by which antibodies to the NMDA receptor disrupt neuronal function and cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that antibodies to the NMDA receptor can change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the cortex, which can then predispose the brain to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We also show that the same changes in microcircuitry can be tolerated in a model of the control condition, but only when the same changes in microcircuitry are induced in the same brain regions. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDA-receptor antibodies. They also suggest that the same changes in microcircuitry can be tolerated in the control condition, but only when the same changes in microcircuitry are induced in the same brain regions. This suggests that the same brain regions may be particularly vulnerable to the effects of antibodies to the NMDA receptor. The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. The study of these events is complicated by the fact that they are superimposed on longer-term greenhouse climate states. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to an increase in atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification, which may have been driven by an increase in the intensity of ocean circulation. This study highlights the importance of studying abrupt climate change in the context of longer-term greenhouse climate states. (Show more)

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having the desired impact on deforestation, and that broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations are necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results also suggest that certification may be having a positive impact on the sustainability of palm oil, but that the benefits of certification are limited by the fact that most plantations are already degraded. We recommend that the RSPO consider the use of a carbon price to incentivize the conversion of degraded land to certified production. Such a policy would have the added benefit of reducing the risk of deforestation in the first place.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the movement of vesicles to the plasma membrane and the formation of the fusion pore. The exocyst complex is conserved from bacteria to humans, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, sex determination can be polygenic, where multiple alleles interact to determine sex. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two alleles interact to produce four possible sexes. We find that polygenic sex determination can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the acquisition of a new sex determination allele can produce additional axes of variation for secondary sexual characteristics. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the accumulation of lipid-soluble molecules that are photooxidized and degraded. These processes are accelerated by the presence of iron, which is a key component of the photooxidized molecules. We show that the presence of iron in the retina promotes the photooxidation and degradation of a class of molecules that are important for the maintenance of photoreceptor cell health. These findings have implications for the understanding of retinal diseases in which iron accumulation is a feature. They also have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies to reduce the oxidative damage and degradation of lipids in the retina. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity and ecosystem services. However, the evolution of predator specialization is often considered a dead end, as morphological and functional optimizations are expected to be lost in the process. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type can evolve into specialists on other prey types. These findings help to understand the evolution of predator specialization, and the role of morphological evolution in the diversification of food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure, and the evolution of the modern human hand is a major focus of hominin research. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, in a Middle Pleistocene hominin from East Africa. This fossil suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding is important for understanding the evolution of the human hand and the emergence of modern human-like tool use. It also has implications for the evolution of the human hand in the context of the origins of modern humans. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule dual inhibitor of human serine hydroxymethyltransferse 1/2, which blocks tumor growth in a colon cancer xenograft model. We have also identified a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type that is particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. These findings provide a rationale for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a class of cancer therapeutics. They also suggest that targeting the one-carbon unit may be a promising strategy for the treatment of lymphoma. This strategy is distinct from the folate pathway, which is defective in many cancers. Thus, the SHMT pathway may be a promising target for the treatment of cancers that are resistant to the folate pathway. This is an important advance in the development of cancer therapeutics. The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is increasingly being recognized, but the evidence is still limited. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of micronutrients. The results also show that forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which is a positive finding. The findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a causal inference approach to study the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This is a relatively new approach in the field of nutrition and environmental research. We believe that it will become increasingly important in the future. (PsycINFO Database Record

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanized system, with the weight of farm machinery now exceeding that of the largest land animals that walked Earth. This has led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers, with potential loss of soil productivity. We show that subsoil compaction is now a global phenomenon, affecting 20% of arable land, and that the weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest land animals. This raises the question of whether prehistoric animals, such as sauropods, would have been able to roam freely over the landscape, as they did in the past, or whether they would have been constrained by the effects of subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods would have been constrained by the effects of subsoil compaction, and that this may have guided their ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails. This may have been a key factor in the success of sauropods in their habitat. (Show more)
